instruction: Define the ONTOLOGY primitive in RP-Lang terms.
output: Primitive: ONTOLOGY. Role: classify and name entities; establish identity and membership so relations know what they are operating on. Typical relation: ONTOLOGY(entity, kind=Prey, tags=[green]).

instruction: Define the GEOMETRY primitive in RP-Lang terms.
output: Primitive: GEOMETRY. Role: spatial/structural organization—adjacency, containment, distance, layout. Typical relation: GEOMETRY(button inside panel, padding=8) or GEOMETRY(predator near prey, radius=80).

instruction: Define the DYNAMICS primitive in RP-Lang terms.
output: Primitive: DYNAMICS. Role: change of state over time—movement, energy gain/loss, growth, decay. Typical relation: DYNAMICS(prey, velocity=rand_walk) or DYNAMICS(resource, regrow_after=100 ticks).

instruction: Define the CONSTRAINT primitive in RP-Lang terms.
output: Primitive: CONSTRAINT. Role: boundary conditions and clamping—min/max, collision bounds, conservation. Typical relation: CONSTRAINT(agent, bounds=[10,590]) to keep entities on-screen.

instruction: Define the EPISTEMIC primitive in RP-Lang terms.
output: Primitive: EPISTEMIC. Role: sensing/knowledge of other entities or world state. Typical relation: EPISTEMIC(prey senses predator, radius=50) or EPISTEMIC(agent sees resource positions).

instruction: Define the META primitive in RP-Lang terms.
output: Primitive: META. Role: rules about rules—handlers that watch events/relations and create/modify others. Typical relation: META(on_button_click create Predator entity).

instruction: Explain how ONTOLOGY handles composition and inheritance in RP-Lang.
output: Use ONTOLOGY to declare kinds and composed kinds; avoid implicit inheritance. Example: ONTOLOGY(drone, kind=Vehicle); ONTOLOGY(sensor_pack, kind=Module); GEOMETRY(sensor_pack attached_to drone); optional ONTOLOGY(drone, traits=[aerial, scout]). Composition is explicit via relations; ONTOLOGY carries identity/kind tags used by other primitives.

instruction: Translate this natural spec into RP relations.
input: A panel contains two buttons. Clicking “Add Prey” spawns a prey agent at a random position; clicking “Add Predator” spawns a predator. Agents stay within the 10–590 bounds.
output: Entities: panel P, buttons Bp (Add Prey), Bd (Add Predator). Relations: GEOMETRY(Bp inside P, padding=8); GEOMETRY(Bd inside P, padding=8, below= Bp). CONSTRAINT(P, bounds=[10,590]); CONSTRAINT(Bp, bounds=[10,590]); CONSTRAINT(Bd, bounds=[10,590]). META(on_click Bp => create entity kind=Prey at rand_pos within bounds); META(on_click Bd => create entity kind=Predator at rand_pos within bounds). ONTOLOGY tags on created entities set their kind.

instruction: Explain this RP world in natural language without leaving the primitives.
input: Entities: Predator p1, Prey q1. Relations: GEOMETRY(p1 near q1, radius=80); EPISTEMIC(p1 senses q1, radius=80); DYNAMICS(p1, chase_target=q1, speed=2); DYNAMICS(q1, flee_target=p1, speed=1.5); CONSTRAINT(p1, bounds=[10,590]); CONSTRAINT(q1, bounds=[10,590]).
output: A predator and a prey exist. Geometry sets a proximity radius between them; epistemic sensing lets the predator know the prey’s position. Dynamics make the predator move toward the prey and the prey flee. Constraints keep both inside the 10–590 box.

instruction: Translate this GUI layout spec into RP relations.
input: A window has a header at the top, a content panel filling the rest, and a Save button anchored at the bottom right with 12px padding. All widgets stay within the 0–800 by 0–600 bounds.
output: Entities: window W, header H, content C, button S. Relations: GEOMETRY(H top_of W, height=60); GEOMETRY(C below H, fills_remaining=True, margin=0); GEOMETRY(S inside W, anchor=bottom_right, padding=12). CONSTRAINT(W, bounds=[0,0,800,600]); CONSTRAINT(H, bounds=[0,0,800,600]); CONSTRAINT(C, bounds=[0,0,800,600]); CONSTRAINT(S, bounds=[0,0,800,600]). ONTOLOGY tags for H/C/S as widget kinds.

instruction: Translate this behavior spec into RP relations.
input: Prey wander randomly, lose 1 energy per tick, eat resources when within 5 units to gain 3 energy, and die when energy drops to 0.
output: Entities: Prey p*, Resources r*. Relations: DYNAMICS(p, velocity=random_walk, energy_drain=1); GEOMETRY(p near r, radius=5); CONSTRAINT(r, consumed_when_near=True); DYNAMICS(r, regrow_after=100); CONSTRAINT(p, death_threshold=0, remove_on_death=True); ONTOLOGY(p, kind=Prey); ONTOLOGY(r, kind=Resource).

instruction: Translate this sensing/constraint spec into RP relations.
input: A drone senses entities within 30 units, reports sightings to a base, cannot enter a rectangular no-fly zone, and loses 2 energy per tick until it docks at the base to recharge.
output: Entities: Drone d, Base b, NoFly zone nf. Relations: EPISTEMIC(d senses any entity, radius=30, report_to=b); GEOMETRY(d avoids nf, exclusion=True); CONSTRAINT(d, bounds=[0,0,500,500]); CONSTRAINT(nf, region=[200,200,300,300]); DYNAMICS(d, energy_drain=2, recharge_at=b); ONTOLOGY(d, kind=Drone); ONTOLOGY(b, kind=Base); ONTOLOGY(nf, kind=Zone).

instruction: Translate this composition spec into RP relations.
input: A factory has robots of kind Assembler and Inspectors. Assemblers carry Tool modules; Inspectors carry Sensor modules. All operate on a line within bounds 0–1000 by 0–200. Assemblers create items; Inspectors flag defective items when sensors detect anomalies within 5 units.
output: Entities: Factory F, Robots a* (Assembler), i* (Inspector), Tool modules t*, Sensor modules s*, Items x*. Relations: ONTOLOGY(a, kind=Assembler); ONTOLOGY(i, kind=Inspector); ONTOLOGY(t, kind=Tool); ONTOLOGY(s, kind=Sensor); GEOMETRY(t attached_to a); GEOMETRY(s attached_to i); CONSTRAINT(a, bounds=[0,0,1000,200]); CONSTRAINT(i, bounds=[0,0,1000,200]); DYNAMICS(a, create_item=x_new at station); EPISTEMIC(i senses anomalies on x within 5); META(on anomaly => CONSTRAINT(x, defective=True)).

instruction: Identify and fix the primitive misuse.
input: Relations: CONSTRAINT(predator, chase_target=prey, speed=2).
output: Problem: chasing is a state transition, not a boundary. Use DYNAMICS. Corrected: DYNAMICS(predator, chase_target=prey, speed=2). Keep CONSTRAINT only for bounds or limits if needed.

instruction: Identify and fix the primitive misuse.
input: Relations: GEOMETRY(prey senses predator, radius=60).
output: Problem: sensing is epistemic, not spatial structure. Use EPISTEMIC for knowledge, keep GEOMETRY for positions/distances. Corrected: EPISTEMIC(prey senses predator, radius=60); optional GEOMETRY(prey near predator, radius=60) if spatial proximity is also required.

instruction: Identify and fix the missing ONTOLOGY tag.
input: META(on_click button => create entity with velocity=1, energy=5).
output: Problem: created entity has no identity/kind. Add ONTOLOGY. Corrected: META(on_click button => create entity e_new); ONTOLOGY(e_new, kind=Prey); DYNAMICS(e_new, velocity=1, energy_drain=1, energy=5).

instruction: Identify and fix the primitive misuse.
input: Relations: META(predator senses prey, radius=50).
output: Problem: sensing is EPISTEMIC, not META. Corrected: EPISTEMIC(predator senses prey, radius=50). META should watch events (e.g., on_capture create new prey) rather than encode perception.

instruction: Identify and fix the primitive misuse.
input: Relations: DYNAMICS(agent, bounds=[0,500]).
output: Problem: bounds are constraints, not state transitions. Corrected: CONSTRAINT(agent, bounds=[0,500]); keep DYNAMICS for movement or energy changes.

instruction: Identify and fix the primitive misuse.
input: Relations: EPISTEMIC(agent behind wall blocks movement).
output: Problem: occlusion is geometric, not epistemic. Use GEOMETRY to represent the wall and blocking; use EPISTEMIC for what can be sensed. Corrected: GEOMETRY(wall blocks line between agent and target); EPISTEMIC(agent senses target, blocked_by=wall).

instruction: Run one evaluator step. Show resulting state changes.
input: Entities: Resource r1 at (100,100) with active=True; Prey q1 at (102,103), energy=10. Relations: GEOMETRY(q1 near r1, radius=5); DYNAMICS(q1, energy_drain=1); DYNAMICS(r1, regrow_after=100); CONSTRAINT(r1, consumed_when_near=True).
output: Step result: GEOMETRY detects proximity. CONSTRAINT marks r1 consumed → r1.active=False. DYNAMICS on q1: energy=9 after drain, plus grazing bonus (+2) from consumption ⇒ energy=11. DYNAMICS on r1 schedules regrow timer toward 100 ticks (state regrow_counter=1).

instruction: Run one evaluator step for a button click that spawns an entity.
input: Event: click on Add Prey button Bp. Entities: Panel P (bounds 0–600), Button Bp inside P. Relations: GEOMETRY(Bp inside P, padding=8); CONSTRAINT(P, bounds=[0,600]); CONSTRAINT(Bp, bounds=[0,600]); META(on_click Bp => create Prey with random position in bounds, energy=12); ONTOLOGY(Bp, kind=Button).
output: Step result: META triggers on click, creates new entity p_new. ONTOLOGY sets p_new kind=Prey. GEOMETRY assigns p_new position within [0,600]. CONSTRAINT applies bounds to p_new. DYNAMICS default for Prey (energy_drain=1) is attached if defined globally; state p_new.energy=12. Existing entities unchanged.

instruction: Run one evaluator step for predator hunting two prey.
input: Entities: Predator p1 at (50,50), energy=20; Prey q1 at (80,50), q2 at (200,50). Relations: GEOMETRY(p1 near q1, radius=80); GEOMETRY(p1 near q2, radius=80); EPISTEMIC(p1 senses prey within 80); DYNAMICS(p1, chase_nearest=True, speed=2, energy_drain=2); CONSTRAINT(p1, bounds=[0,300]).
output: Step result: EPISTEMIC observes prey; GEOMETRY distances pick q1 as nearest. DYNAMICS moves p1 toward q1 by speed 2 (new position ~ (52,50)), energy drops to 18. CONSTRAINT clamps position if needed (not triggered). No capture yet; hunting relation persists for next step.

instruction: Run one evaluator step where an agent hits a boundary.
input: Entities: Agent a at (798,100), velocity=(5,0). Relations: DYNAMICS(a, velocity=(5,0)); CONSTRAINT(a, bounds=[0,0,800,600], clamp=True); GEOMETRY(a inside world).
output: Step result: Proposed position is (803,100); CONSTRAINT clamps x to 800. Final position (800,100). If clamp resets velocity, set vx=0; otherwise keep vx=5 for next step. DYNAMICS applies no other changes this tick.

instruction: Run one evaluator step where movement depends on sensing.
input: Entities: Scout s at (0,0), Target t at (40,0). Relations: EPISTEMIC(s senses t, radius=30); DYNAMICS(s, move_toward_if_seen=t, speed=3); CONSTRAINT(s, bounds=[0,0,100,100]).
output: Step result: EPISTEMIC fails (distance 40 > 30), so DYNAMICS does not move s. Position stays (0,0). CONSTRAINT not triggered. State unchanged for next step.

instruction: Run one evaluator step where occlusion blocks sensing but not proximity.
input: Entities: Agent a at (0,0), Target t at (10,0), Wall w between them. Relations: GEOMETRY(w blocks line between a and t); GEOMETRY(a near t, radius=12); EPISTEMIC(a senses t, requires_clear_los=True, radius=12); DYNAMICS(a, move_toward_if_seen=t, speed=2).
output: Step result: GEOMETRY reports proximity within 12, but occluder w blocks line-of-sight. EPISTEMIC fails (no clear LOS), so DYNAMICS does not move a. Positions unchanged. If META recomputes visibility graphs, epistemic relation would remain inactive until geometry changes.

instruction: Run one evaluator step with a conservation constraint and adjustment.
input: Entities: Battery b with energy=50; Agent a draws energy=10 this tick. Relations: DYNAMICS(a, energy_drain=10); CONSTRAINT(total_energy=50, adjust_reservoir=True); META(conservation_guard enabled).
output: Step result: DYNAMICS would reduce b.energy to 40. CONSTRAINT+META conservation_guard compares total energy to baseline (50); detects shortfall of 10. It adds 10 to a reservoir entity (or rejects the overdraw if no reservoir). State: b.energy=40; reservoir.energy increased by 10; total remains 50.

instruction: Run one evaluator step resolving overlapping GUI elements.
input: Entities: Panel P (0–400x0–300), Buttons b1 at (10,10) size (100,30), b2 at (50,20) size (120,30). Relations: GEOMETRY(b1 inside P); GEOMETRY(b2 inside P); CONSTRAINT(no_overlap=True, resolve_by=stack_vertical); META(layout_engine enabled).
output: Step result: META layout_engine detects overlap between b1 and b2. Using resolve_by=stack_vertical, it adjusts b2 position to (10, 10+30+8)= (10,48) with spacing 8. GEOMETRY updates b2 coords; CONSTRAINT satisfied (no overlap). DYNAMICS unchanged.

instruction: Run one evaluator step that includes a GCO closure after production.
input: Loop state: Agents evaluate relations. Event: META creates a new entity e_new (Production). Relations: META(on production => trigger GCO); CONSTRAINT(resolve_conflicts=True); DYNAMICS(update_positions=True).
output: Step result: Production occurs (e_new created). META triggers GCO closure: halts further relation firing this tick, runs CONSTRAINT to resolve conflicts, commits ONTOLOGY/DYNAMICS state (positions, energy), and emits Reset for next loop. No additional DYNAMICS after closure. Next tick resumes from the committed world.

instruction: Describe how META operates in the ecosystem demo.
output: META watches GUI events and relation outcomes to create or modify relations/entities. Example: on button click, META creates a new Prey or Predator entity, attaches ONTOLOGY kind, sets GEOMETRY position, CONSTRAINT bounds, and DYNAMICS/EPISTEMIC relations. META can also spawn hunting relations on-the-fly between new predators and existing prey.

instruction: Explain a META rule that auto-adds hunting relations when new prey appear.
output: META listens for ONTOLOGY(kind=Prey) creations. When a new prey q_new appears, META creates GEOMETRY(predator near q_new, radius=80), EPISTEMIC(predator senses q_new), and DYNAMICS(predator, chase_target=q_new) for each predator. This keeps the hunting graph updated without manual wiring.

instruction: Describe a META rule that builds visibility graphs when walls change.
output: META watches GEOMETRY changes to occluder entities (walls). On change, META rebuilds EPISTEMIC visibility relations: for each agent pair, if line-of-sight is clear per current GEOMETRY, set EPISTEMIC(agent sees target, radius=los_distance); otherwise remove that sensing relation. This keeps epistemic knowledge consistent with geometry edits.

instruction: Describe a META rule that enforces conservation when dynamics update energy.
output: META hooks DYNAMICS updates to energy. After each step, it sums energy across entities and checks CONSTRAINT(total_energy == baseline). If violated, META adjusts a global reservoir entity to compensate, or rejects the violating DYNAMICS update. This is a rule-about-rules ensuring conservation constraints hold.

instruction: Describe a META rule that throttles actuation when safety constraints are breached.
output: META monitors CONSTRAINT(safety_ok) on actuators. If safety_ok=False, META disables or caps DYNAMICS commands (e.g., velocity<=0) and injects CONSTRAINT(no_actuation=True) until safety_ok=True. When cleared, META restores original DYNAMICS. This keeps actuation rules bound to safety constraints.

instruction: Describe a META rule that enforces ONTOLOGY schemas on new entities.
output: META listens for entity creation. For each new entity, it checks ONTOLOGY kind against a schema table; if required relations are missing (e.g., GEOMETRY position, CONSTRAINT bounds), META adds them or rejects the creation. This keeps worlds consistent with declared kinds.

instruction: Describe the GCO cycle and how it relates to RP primitives.
output: GCO (Global Closure Operator) wraps the evaluator: Loop (relations fire) → Null (gating/sync) → Production (externalized action) → Closure (enforce coherence) → Reset. META can host the closure logic; CONSTRAINT resolves conflicts; DYNAMICS/GEOMETRY/EPISTEMIC state is frozen at closure; ONTOLOGY identities are stabilized. Stopping condition: GCO fires only on production events, then resets for the next loop.

instruction: Describe a META rule that triggers GCO closure when production occurs.
output: META watches for Production events (e.g., new relation/entity creation or external act). When triggered, it enters Closure: halts further relation firing, applies CONSTRAINT to resolve conflicts, commits ONTOLOGY/DYNAMICS state, and emits a reset signal for the next loop. This teaches the model when to stop stepping and finalize state.

instruction: Apply GCO to handle contradictory ONTOLOGY assignments.
input:
ONTOLOGY(a, kind=Prey)
ONTOLOGY(a, kind=Predator)
output: GCO detects contradictory identity for entity a. Closure requires a consistent ONTOLOGY: choose one kind or escalate to META for resolution. Minimal canonical outcome: one ONTOLOGY assignment; conflicting one removed or flagged.

instruction: Apply GCO to prune redundant relations.
input:
GEOMETRY(a near b, radius=10)
GEOMETRY(a near b, radius=10)
output: GCO sees duplicate GEOMETRY relations with identical payloads. Closure keeps one canonical relation and removes the redundant copy. No state change beyond deduplication.

instruction: Check if the relational set is already in closure.
input:
GEOMETRY(a near b, radius=10)
DYNAMICS(a, speed=1)
output: No contradictions, no duplicates, no unresolved dependencies. GCO reports closure achieved; state is a fixed point for this tick. No META intervention required.

instruction: Show when GCO requires META intervention to resolve ambiguity.
input:
ONTOLOGY(a, kind=Vehicle)
DYNAMICS(a, velocity=1)
CONSTRAINT(a, max_velocity=0.5)
output: GCO finds conflict between DYNAMICS velocity and CONSTRAINT max_velocity. Closure cannot pick a resolution; it flags META to adjust (clamp velocity) or reject the violating DYNAMICS. Outcome depends on META policy; closure pending until resolved.
